subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
Uncertain. There are various possible explanations:
# The traditional glyph origin given in ''{{w|Shuowen}}'' explains the character to be a {{liushu|p|nocap=1}} of female genitalia.
# It is possibly a {{liushu|p|nocap=1}} of an ancient funnel or wash basin. It may be an early form of {{zh-l|*匜}}.
# It was once interchangeable with {{zh-l|*它}} and may have originated as a simplification.
# It may have been created to represent the modal particle ({{zh-l|語氣詞}}). In some bronze inscriptions, it appears to be a mouth ({{zh-l|*口}}) with a curved line descending from it to represent air coming out of the mouth.

subSections.title: Readings
Etymology
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|なり|yomi=k}}
From classical Japanese {{m|ja|なり|tr=nari}}, a contraction of {{m|ja|に|tr=ni}} and {{m|ja|あり|tr=ari}}.

subSections.title: Pronunciation
subSections.text: {{ja-pron|なり|y=k}}

subSections.title: Verb
subSections.text:
{{ja-verb|なり}}

# {{n-g|The classical Japanese copula “[[to be]]”, equivalent to modern Japanese {{m|ja|である|tr=de aru}} or {{m|ja|だ|tr=da}}.}}

subSections.title: Derived terms
Usage notes
subSections.text: The kanji form is usually used to denote a sum of money, e.g. {{m|ja|[[二]][[千]][[円]][[也]]|tr=nisen en nari}}. <!-- also in the Nyaruko OP "Koi wa KAOSU no Shimobe nari" -->
